title: Multi-Agent Architecture Foundation
goal: Transform LifeVault into a multi-agent orchestration system with reasoning and persistent memory

tasks: Review your current LifeVault MCP tools (log_workout, log_meal, etc)
Sketch multi-agent architecture diagram on paper/whiteboard
Define 4 agent roles: Coach Agent (workout recommendations), Nutrition Agent (meal planning), Analytics Agent (pattern recognition), Memory Agent (retrieval)
Map out communication flows between agents
Document agent responsibilities in a design doc (Markdown file)
Create new folder: lifevault-orchestrator/
Initialize Node.js project: npm init
Install dependencies: @azure/service-bus, redis, uuid, dotenv
Build orchestrator.js - main entry point that receives user queries
Implement query classification logic (determine which agent should handle request)
Create agent router function that forwards queries to appropriate agent
Add basic logging to track routing decisions
9:30am_12:00pm.deliverable: Working orchestrator that can classify and route queries

tasks: Create agents/ folder with 4 stub files: coachAgent.js, nutritionAgent.js, analyticsAgent.js, memoryAgent.js
Each agent implements handleQuery(query, context) function
Set up Azure Service Bus namespace in Azure Portal (or use Redis if simpler)
Create 4 queues/topics: coach-queue, nutrition-queue, analytics-queue, memory-queue
Implement message sending from orchestrator to agent queues
Implement message receiving in each agent stub
Test basic message flow: orchestrator -> coach agent -> response
1:00pm_3:30pm.deliverable: 4 agent stubs communicating via message bus
azure_setup: Create Service Bus namespace in Azure Portal

tasks: Write test queries: 'I just ran 5k', 'What should I eat for dinner?', 'How am I trending this week?'
Verify orchestrator routes each query to correct agent
Check logs to confirm message delivery
Update Agent_Architecture_Design.md with implementation notes
Commit all code to Git: 'feat: orchestrator and agent stubs with message bus'
Push to GitHub
4:00pm_5:00pm.deliverable: Tested routing system, code in Git

tasks: Create contextManager.js for shared state across agents
Implement conversation history storage (in-memory for now, Redis later)
Add context object structure: { userId, conversationId, history[], currentIntent, timestamp }
Build context injection: attach context to every agent query
Build context updates: agents can write back to shared context
Test: verify agents can see previous conversation turns
7:00am_9:30am.deliverable: Working context management that agents share

tasks: Open coachAgent.js and implement full logic
Connect Coach Agent to Azure OpenAI with system prompt defining its role
Give Coach Agent access to Memory Agent (can query workout history)
Implement reasoning: 'Based on your last 3 workouts, you should rest' or 'Time for legs day'
Add tool use: Coach Agent can call getRecentWorkouts from your existing MCP tools
Test with real queries: 'What workout should I do today?'
Verify Coach Agent retrieves past data and gives personalized advice
10:00am_12:30pm.deliverable: Fully functional Coach Agent with reasoning

tasks: Implement memoryAgent.js with query handling
Connect to Azure Table Storage (your existing workout/meal tables)
Build simple semantic search: keyword matching on workout/meal descriptions
Implement queryMemory(question) function that returns relevant past entries
Test queries: 'When did I last do heavy squats?', 'What did I eat yesterday?'
Document retrieval accuracy and limitations
1:30pm_3:30pm.deliverable: Memory Agent that retrieves relevant past data
1:30pm_3:30pm.note: This is simplified retrieval - Weekend 3-4 will add vector embeddings

tasks: Test complete flow: User query -> Orchestrator -> Coach Agent -> Memory Agent -> Response
Verify context is maintained across multi-turn conversations
Test inter-agent communication: Coach asks Memory for data
Document agent interaction logs
Update architecture diagram with actual implementation details
Commit to Git: 'feat: coach and memory agents with context management'
Write README.md explaining how the multi-agent system works
success_criteria: Memory Agent successfully retrieves past data

tasks: Implement nutritionAgent.js similar to Coach Agent
System prompt: nutritionist giving meal recommendations based on workout data
Tool use: can query recent meals and workouts to suggest nutrition
Implement analyticsAgent.js for pattern recognition
Analytics Agent calculates: workout frequency, meal patterns, energy trends
Test: 'What should I eat to recover from yesterday's workout?'
Test: 'How am I trending this month?'
Sign up for Pinecone free tier OR set up Azure AI Search
Create new index: 'lifevault-memories'
Install SDK: npm install @pinecone-database/pinecone (or @azure/search-documents)
Build memory storage function: store workout/meal summaries with metadata
Test storing: convert last 10 workouts into vector embeddings (use Azure OpenAI embeddings API)
Verify embeddings are stored in vector DB
Build simple retrieval query
10:00am_12:30pm.deliverable: Vector database storing your workout/meal memories
10:00am_12:30pm.note: This sets foundation for Weekend 3-4 RAG work

tasks: Update Coach Agent with chain-of-thought prompting
Add reasoning steps: '1. Check recent workouts, 2. Assess recovery, 3. Recommend workout'
Log reasoning traces to see agent's decision process
Implement in Analytics Agent: show step-by-step how it calculates trends
Test with complex query: 'Should I workout today or rest?'
Verify you can see the agent's reasoning in logs
1:30pm_3:30pm.benefit: Makes AI decisions explainable and debuggable

tasks: Run comprehensive test suite with all 4 agents
Test inter-agent collaboration: Coach asks Analytics for trends, then makes recommendation
Verify vector memory store is working
Document reasoning traces in examples.md
Update architecture diagram with vector DB
Commit: 'feat: all 4 agents operational with reasoning and vector memory'
Push to GitHub
Research tree-of-thought prompting pattern
Implement in Coach Agent for complex decisions
Pattern: Generate 3 possible workout plans, evaluate each, select best
Add branching logic: agent explores multiple reasoning paths
Log decision tree to visualize thought process
Test with: 'Plan my workouts for the next 3 days'
7:00am_9:30am.advanced_feature: Puts you ahead of basic AI engineers

tasks: Scenario: Coach Agent wants hard workout, Nutrition Agent flags low recent calories
Build negotiation protocol: agents can challenge each other's recommendations
Implement conflict resolution: agents discuss and reach consensus
Add priority weighting: health/safety concerns override performance goals
Test conflicting scenario: push hard vs. rest due to poor nutrition
Log negotiation process
10:00am_12:30pm.deliverable: Agents that negotiate and resolve conflicts
10:00am_12:30pm.innovation: Most multi-agent systems don't have this - you're ahead

tasks: Implement goal decomposition in Analytics Agent
User sets goal: 'Run a 5k in under 25 minutes'
Agent breaks into subtasks: build endurance, increase speed, track progress
Create task queue that Coach Agent uses to plan workouts
Add progress tracking: measure distance to goal each week
Test: set a fitness goal and see multi-week plan generated
1:30pm_3:30pm.practical_value: Makes LifeVault actually useful for your real fitness goals

tasks: Write comprehensive Agent_System_Documentation.md
Include: architecture diagram, agent roles, reasoning examples, interaction flows
Create demo video (screen recording) showing multi-agent conversations
Update your lifevault_12week_tracker.json: set Weekend 1-2 status to 'COMPLETED'
List achievements: 4 agents, reasoning, memory, negotiation, goal planning
Identify blockers or challenges for retrospective
Commit final code: 'docs: complete Weekend 1-2 multi-agent system documentation'
Celebrate! You just built something most AI engineers haven't.
4:00pm_5:00pm.deliverable: Complete Weekend 1-2 with documentation and demo

weekend_1_2_complete_when: Orchestrator routes queries to correct agents
Context management working (agents share conversation history)
All code documented and in Git

tips_for_success: Start EXACTLY at 7 AM Saturday - momentum matters
Take all scheduled breaks - prevents burnout
If stuck >30 min, move to next task and revisit later
Commit to Git after every major task (not just end of day)
Keep VS Code, Azure Portal, and docs open in separate monitors
Test incrementally - don't wait until end to verify things work
Log everything - reasoning traces are your portfolio evidence
If ahead of schedule, start Weekend 3-4 prep (vector DB research)
